heisig_chinese_memo: A person running, her arms raised up, because she caught on fire!
heisig_story: Just as sitting before a fire enlivens the imagination and lets you see almost anything you want to in the flames, this kanji is so simple it lets you see almost any sort of fire you want to see. It no longer makes a good pictograph, but I invite you to take a pencil and paper and play with the form - first writing it as shown below and then adding lines here and there - to see what you can come up with. Everything from matchbooks to cigarette lighters to volcanic eruptions to the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah have been found here. No doubt you, too, will find something interesting to bend your memory around these four simple strokes.
koohiiStory1: For some reason, this kanji reminds me of a person running, her arms (the two drops) raised up, because she caught on fire!
koohiiStory2: A tepee getting shot at by fire arrows.

WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic:
Whenever we need to remember ã‹, we use the word car.
For this kanji, when we think fire, we ought to think of something on fire. What's on fire? It's obviously your very own car (ã‹)! Oh Goddd NOOO!
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Oh no... Oh no!! If you don't have a car, imagine what it'd feel like if your car just exploded and burned down. If you do have a car, imagine your own car in this situation. It should be a terrible feeling, if you imagine it well enough. So, when you think fire, remember the fear you had when your car was given to the flames. Now you have to walk everywhere, sad :(

origin_of_ch_char_book: The monument features the three supreme existences of the Universe: Heaven (å¤©), Earth(åœ°), and Human (äºº)â€” and the five basic elements of the universe: water(æ°´), fire(ç«), iron (é‡‘), wood(æœ¨), soil(åœŸ) (14th-19th century) ,Woman writing with a brush pen (18thâ€“19th century) In modern China, this is the character that is used to signify reading a book: (æ›¸, ä¹¦, shu, book) On the top there is a hand, and underneath the character is the bottom of the tree (æœ¬, ben, root). Like the stump of a tree, a person holds a long, stubby pen tool. Below is a fire (ç«, huo, fire) burning for the ancestral rite, and a mouth that means words at the rite. This character describes someone recording the words of various people performing at the memorial service. It is now used to mean a book. (è«–, è®º, lun, essay; discuss) The left symbolizes a forthright statement like a spear (è¨€, yan, speak). Upper right corner is a roof or lid that collects something in it. And there are wood pieces with various records tied up together . The ancients have written a lot of records on bamboo sticks, and they discuss together whether these records are right or wrong. Therefore, this character has become to mean logical theory or a rational discussion.,The ancient Chinese considered that there were five essential elements in the universe: Water (æ°´, shui), Fire (ç«, huo), Wood (æœ¨, mu), Iron (é‡‘, jin), and Earth (åœŸ, tu). The five main elements interact and create each other or restrain each other. For example, the tree burns and creates fire which burns down to ashes and becomes earth (soil). Water restrains fire and fire can melt metal. (äº”, wu, five) contains such philosophical meanings. The top line means sky , the bottom line is earth , and the middle shows how the â€œfive elementsâ€ cross and interact with each other.
humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: The oracle " fire " is like a rising flame, more dynamic than the shape of a mountain. The original meaning is fire.

The characters " fire " and " mountain " in the oracle bone inscriptions are not easy to distinguish. The biggest difference is that " fire " has two points and " mountain " does not, but " fire " is often not added. The bottom curvature of " mountain " and " fire " are also different. The character for " mountain " is generally flat, and the character for " fire " is generally curved. Scholars generally distinguish two characters from their rhetoric. See " mountain ". The word " fire " is not seen in the inscriptions. The character " Fire " in the Warring States period was lined up, and a stroke that was originally tilted up from left to right was written down to left and right, and a horizontal pen was added to the vertical pen for modification.

The word " fire " oracle bone inscriptions is used as the original meaning, such as "He Ji" 30774: "Fire does not extend." Extension means continuation, the whole sentence means that fire will not continue. It can also be used as a star name, that is, Mars, or Antares. For example, "Collection" 11503: "ã¢ (Yes) new big stars are on fire." And there is the meaning of juxtaposition (Liu Xinglong). "The Book of Songs. Bin Feng. "July": "July Flowing Fire ", also using " Fire " as the abbreviation for Mars. The word " fire " in Oracle can also be used as a name.

Because the sounds of " fire " and " misfortune " are close, and " fire " is also one of the disasters, " fire " can also be used as " misfortune " in the inscriptions (Chen Weizhan). For example, "Collection" 34797: "Death in ten days (no) fire" means that there is no disaster in ten days.

"Shuowen": "Fire, ruin. Travel in the south, the flame will rise. Pictogram. All fire belongs to the fire." "Fire, ruin also" belongs to the sound training, referring to the flame when an object burns.
humanum_short_description_en: Oracle is like a fire, the original meaning is flame.

origin_of_ch_char_book: The monument features the three supreme existences of the Universe: Heaven (å¤©), Earth(åœ°), and Human (äºº)â€” and the five basic elements of the universe: water(æ°´), fire(ç«), iron (é‡‘), wood(æœ¨), soil(åœŸ) (14th-19th century),Woman writing with a brush pen (18thâ€“19th century)In modern China, this is the character that is used to signify reading a book: (æ›¸, ä¹¦, shu, book) On the top there is a hand, and underneath the character is the bottom of the tree (æœ¬, ben, root). Like the stump of a tree, a person holds a long, stubby pen tool. Below is a fire (ç«, huo, fire) burning for the ancestral rite, and a mouth that means words at the rite. This character describes someone recording the words of various people performing at the memorial service. It is now used to mean a book. (è«–, è®º, lun, essay; discuss) The left symbolizes a forthright statement like a spear (è¨€, yan, speak). Upper right corner is a roof or lid that collects something in it. And there are wood pieces with various records tied up together . The ancients have written a lot of records on bamboo sticks, and they discuss together whether these records are right or wrong. Therefore, this character has become to mean logical theory or a rational discussion.,The ancient Chinese considered that there were five essential elements in the universe: Water (æ°´, shui), Fire (ç«, huo), Wood (æœ¨, mu), Iron (é‡‘, jin), and Earth (åœŸ, tu). The five main elements interact and create each other or restrain each other. For example, the tree burns and creates fire which burns down to ashes and becomes earth (soil). Water restrains fire and fire can melt metal. (äº”, wu, five) contains such philosophical meanings. The top line means sky , the bottom line is earth , and the middle shows how the â€œfive elementsâ€ cross and interact with each other.

Heisig: Just as sitting before a fire enlivens the imagination and lets you see almost anything you want to in the flames, this kanji is so simple it lets you see almost any sort of fire you want to see. It no longer makes a good pictograph, but I invite you to take a pencil and paper and play with the form - first writing it as shown below and then adding lines here and there - to see what you can come up with. Everything from matchbooks to cigarette lighters to volcanic eruptions to the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah have been found here. No doubt you, too, will find something interesting to bend your memory around these four simple strokes.
* To avoid confusion later on, it is best to keep to the meaning of a fireplace (or hearth) or a raging conflagration like a forest fire for this kanji's primitive meaning. Another primitive element for fire, based on this one, is written as 4 small drops and will mean flames, cauldron, cooking fire, or an oven fire.

Elaboration: The oracle " fire" is like a rising flame, more dynamic than the shape of a mountain. The original meaning is fire. The characters " fire" and " mountain" in the oracle bone inscriptions are not easy to distinguish. The biggest difference is that " fire" has two points and " mountain" does not, but " fire" is often not added. The bottom curvature of " mountain" and " fire" are also different. The character for " mountain" is generally flat, and the character for " fire" is generally curved. Scholars generally distinguish two characters from their rhetoric. See " mountain". The word " fire" is not seen in the inscriptions. The character " Fire" in the Warring States period was lined up, and a stroke that was originally tilted up from left to right was written down to left and right, and a horizontal pen was added to the vertical pen for modification. The word " fire" oracle bone inscriptions is used as the original meaning, such as "He Ji" 30774: "Fire does not extend." Extension means continuation, the whole sentence means that fire will not continue. It can also be used as a star name, that is, Mars, or Antares. For example, "Collection" 11503: "ã¢ (Yes) new big stars are on fire." And there is the meaning of juxtaposition (Liu Xinglong). "The Book of Songs. Bin Feng. "July": "July Flowing Fire", also using " Fire" as the abbreviation for Mars. The word " fire" in Oracle can also be used as a name. Because the sounds of " fire" and " misfortune" are close, and " fire" is also one of the disasters, " fire" can also be used as " misfortune" in the inscriptions (Chen Weizhan). For example, "Collection" 34797: "Death in ten days (no) fire" means that there is no disaster in ten days. "Shuowen": "Fire, ruin. Travel in the south, the flame will rise. Pictogram. All fire belongs to the fire." "Fire, ruin also" belongs to the sound training, referring to the flame when an object burns.

Basic explanation of words
fire
huÇ’
Combustion, the light and flame emitted when a substance burns: firepower. Fire candle. Fire source. flame. Fireworks. Picking chestnuts from the fire (equivalent to others taking risks and contributing, but oneself suffers losses and gains nothing).
Urgent: Quickly. One hundred thousand in a hurry.
Refers to guns, ammunition, etc.: gunpowder. artillery.
Angry, angry: fierce. Fire.
Chinese medicine refers to the cause of inflammation, redness, irritability, etc.: liver fire. Poisonous fire attacked the heart.
Describe the red: flaming red. Ham.
The ancient army organization consisted of ten people in one fire.

Chinese dictionary definition of words
[â‘ ]ï¼»huÇ’ï¼½
["Guangyun" call fruit cut, fruit on, dawn. ]
Also known as "ç¬2".
(1) The light and flame emitted when the object burns.
(2) Incineration; Incineration.
(3) Use fire to cook.
(4) Fire; a fire occurs.
(5) Refers to lamps or torches.
(6) Sight with fire light.
(7) In ancient times, it refers to thunder and lightning, electric light.
(8) Light.
(9) Hot, hot air.
(10) Describe red.
(11) Yu is important; urgent.
(12) Yu anger.
(13) Refers to anger.
(14) Yu strong feelings or desires.
(15) Refers to the smoking and roasting of tea leaves.
(16) One of the five elements.
(17) Refers to flame-shaped patterns in ancient costumes.
(18) TCM refers to the cause of symptoms such as irritability, inflammation, redness and swelling.
(19) Ancient military units. Ten people make fire.
(20) Refers to a group of several people.
(21) Refers to the cold food festival. See "before the fire" and "after the fire".
(22) Still years and years.
(23) Refers to guns and ammunition. See "Firepower", "Fire Net", "Firearms".
(24) Star name. Refers to the fire. That is Antares.
(25) Star name. One of the planets. That is, Yingluo.
(26) Last name. The Three Kingdoms Shu has a fire economy. See "ZhengzitongÂ·Fire Department".
